newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Brazil re-election push must wait for split allies.
newsitem.headline: Brazil re-election push must wait for split allies.

text.p: The Brazilian government is in a hurry to approve a bill allowing President Fernando Henrique Cardoso to stand again, but it cannot rush two big political parties whose votes are key to its success, analysts said.

Leaders of parties who make up the government's fragile alliance in Congress decided on Wednesday to postpone until around October 22 the start of committee-level discussions of a constitutional amendment allowing re-election.

The committee's first meeting had been expected next week, paving the way for a first vote on the floor of the Chamber of Deputies this year and a final, second vote before February's changeover in the presidency of the lower house.
The government wants to get the re-election issue through the volatile chamber before Luiz Eduardo Magalhaes, its pro- reform president, is replaced by an as yet unchosen successor.
But the committee's start was delayed by differences within the Brazilian Progressive Party (PPB) and the Brazilian Democratic Movement Party (PMDB), which are split on re-election.

The parties, who total nearly 200 deputies, are essential to the government's chances of pulling off the two three-fifths majorities, each equivalent to 308 votes, needed for the approval of the amendment in the volatile Chamber of Deputies.
"In the re-election race, the government has slowed down on the curve to win on the home stretch," columnist Tereza Cruvinel wrote in newspaper O Globo.
The delay in the start-up of the committee gave the Brazilian Progressive Party (PPB) time to hold a national convention to decide its position on the reform.

The PPB is the party of outgoing Sao Paulo mayor Paulo Maluf whose declared presidential ambitions were bolstered by the strong performance of his would-be successor in last week's first round of municipal elections.
Maluf is considered the biggest single threat to re-election, but has failed consistently over the years to win elections for anything bigger than Sao Paulo town hall.

Some Brasilia-watchers sense he might settle for a deal under which he drops his hostile approach in return for government support of his possible candidacy for the Sao Paulo state governorship in 1998.

"Maluf wants to be president, but he knows that's a long shot," said Marcelo Cordeiro of consultants Santafe Ideais. "His game plan might be to win more space for the PPB in the government and consolidate his own position in the party."

A pro-re-election PPB might be rewarded in a cabinet reshuffle expected some time early next year, bringing it closer to the kind of power enjoyed by the government's closest ally, the Liberal Front Party, Cordeiro said.

The extra week was also seen as a concession to the Brazilian Democratic Movement Party (PMDB), whose anti-Cardoso, old-guard leadership has ordered pro-reform members to stay out of the re-election debate until 1997.

The government may choose to avoid destabilizing the already divided PMDB by delaying until January -- during a special session of Congress to run through the year-end recess -- the committee-level vote on the re-election bill, analysts said.
